english: crooked; askew (also used as a phonetic component)

etymology.interpretation: Mouth 口 supplies the semantic hint of the mouth or an opening, while 冎 contributes the sound. The sense ‘crooked/askew’ likely developed from the image of a mouth set awry or by semantic extension while the phonetic value was retained.

examples.chinese: 这幅画挂得有点咼(這幅畫掛得有點咼)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè fú huà guà de yǒu diǎn guō.
examples.english: The painting is hung a bit askew.

examples.chinese: 风吹后，门框略显咼(風吹後，門框略顯咼)。
examples.pinyin: Fēng chuī hòu, ménkuāng lüè xiǎn guō.
examples.english: After the wind, the doorframe looks slightly crooked.

examples.chinese: 古文中，“咼”常用作声旁(古文中，「咼」常用作聲旁)。
examples.english: In classical texts, “咼” is often used as a phonetic component.
